videos.title: Samsung‚Äôs Wireless Frame Pro TV Is a Disaster (And I‚Äôm Stuck With It)
videos.description: Samsung's new $2,200 Wireless Frame Pro TV is AWFUL! Watch it implode under latency, bugs, and edge‚Äëlit lies. Save on the Rhinoshield AirX at checkout using code "SNAZZYLABS" - https://url.rhinoshield.io/SNAZZYLABS Follow Snazzy Labs on Twitter - https://twitter.com/snazzylabs   Follow me on Bluesky - https://snazzy.fm/UW Follow me on Threads - https://snazzy.fm/XV Follow me on Mastodon - https://snazzy.fm/NN Follow me on Instagram - https://instagram.com/snazzyq  In this Samsung Frame Pro review, I explain why the $2,200 ‚Äúwireless‚Äù TV is a disaster: the Wireless One Connect box causes latency, stutters, and constant disconnects, the micro‚ÄëHDMI 2.1 port lacks eARC/ARC for soundbars, Wi‚ÄëFi 7/6GHz interference breaks stability, and HDMI‚ÄëCEC mangles Art Mode power behavior. Despite the matte panel and convincing Art Mode, the edge‚Äëlit ‚ÄúNeo QLED powered by mini‚ÄëLED‚Äù display delivers poor contrast, vertical banding, smeary night scenes, and unhinged default picture settings‚Äîwith no Dolby Vision. Software is painfully slow (TV Plus bloat), setup is infuriating (mounting/stud issues, cable routing), and even Samsung‚Äôs S801D soundbar drops audio over Wi‚ÄëFi, forcing a lower‚Äëquality Bluetooth fallback. If you want a main TV, buy an OLED; for an art TV, cheaper Hisense/TCL models are better. Bottom line: Samsung Frame Pro looks like wall art, but as a wireless TV it‚Äôs laggy, unreliable, and wildly overpriced.  0:00 - This is the worst TV I've ever owned 0:29 - What's the point of "Frame"-style TVs? 2:39 - How Is It Wireless? 4:15 - Installation HELL 6:45 - eARC sound bar support is ABYSMAL 8:41 - Wireless TV? videos.title: The Unstoppable Rise Of LG TVs (There's No Catching Up)
videos.description: üí° Turn any idea into a production-ready app or website by describing it to AI. Dream it, and Lindy builds it from coding to QA. Try Lindy today using my link üëâüèª https://go.lindy.ai/logically-answered   In the early 2010s, OLED was a joke. Too fragile, too expensive, and impossible to scale. Everyone dropped it except LG. Fast forward to today, and LG owns over half the global OLED market. They even make panels for Samsung and Sony. So what did LG see that everyone else missed? Back in the 2000s, the TV world was all Plasma and LCD. Plasma had the best picture but came with heat, power, and burn-in issues. LCDs were cheap, efficient, and ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù While everyone chased scale, LG doubled down on quality. They bought Kodak‚Äôs OLED patents, poured billions into R&D, and invented WRGB OLED to cut costs. For years, it looked like financial suicide. But when Netflix, gaming, and home theaters exploded, OLED became the gold standard. By 2016, LG had perfected manufacturing, and by 2017, the C7 OLED changed everything. Competitors mocked OLED, then bought LG panels anyway. Now, LG Display supplies Samsung, Sony, and nearly every major brand. The bet no one believed in became the tech no one could live without. comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.
comments.comment_text_original: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

Amazing to see how far TCL has come.

Thanks for the video. Love from Tamil Nadu ‚ù§

comments.comment_text_display:
Firstly, the human eye cannot always perceive the exact colors, and not everyone‚Äôs vision is as trained as a professional‚Äôs. When you buy a TV for your home, you are not going to place it side by side with another TV (that‚Äôs common sense). So, no one can really predict the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù color reproduction in advance. Also, remember that color variation will always be there depending on the environment like how sunlight or artificial light falls on the screen. A living room and a bedroom will show the same TV differently because of light placement.

All TVs are well calibrated(manufacturers are not idiots), but sometimes the same model is tuned slightly differently and sold under another model name. This is because people perceive colors differently. For example, someone who is color-blind might prefer highly saturated images, while another person may find softer colors more natural.

That‚Äôs why I feel YouTube reviews SHOULDN'T be your only guide. The best option is to visit a nearby showroom, see the TVs in person, and then decide. That way, you‚Äôll end up happier with your choice.

comments.comment_text_display:
@Moonblock511 Could you please explain what you mean by a ‚ÄòGood TV‚Äô? Also, do you know who manufactures VA panels, and are there specific models that use them, or is it mainly a difference in color variation among different TV brands?

If you look deeper, the market is flooded with TVs, and most of them are actually made by OEMs. For example, Hisense owns Toshiba TV production rights in many regions, so they come from the same manufacturer. Similarly, TCL and iFalcon are both made by TCL. In fact, TCL‚Äôs panel division, CSOT, is one of the largest producers of VA panels globally.

Other popular brands like Motorola, Xiaomi, OnePlus, and several others get their TVs assembled here in India by companies such as Dixon Technologies or Radiant Appliances, which handle multiple brands under one roof.

So, when you think about it, which TV do you really believe is good for the price? That‚Äôs exactly my point, most of them share same components and what really matters is color tuning, warranty and pricing.

Now, you tell me which TV is a "Good TV"?

comments.comment_text_display: Vineet - You are missing one important aspect in your reviews. That is longevity of the product. Sony brand is not just because of quality but it is quality coupled with longevity. Big brands like Sony or Apple, if you buy them once, even at a high price, you get an assured product for 10+ years. For many customers who do not like to change products every 4-5 years, that's a very big deal. The other thing that Sony historically stands out is the sound quality. Except Panasonic, a fellow Japanese brand, rarely there has been any other brand that has matched Sony's sound optimisation.

comments.comment_text_display:
I have had a TCL 4K TV since 2017 till 2024, great TV great sound with Harman Kardon audio system built into it. The TV was all good until one the floating table fell and was right next to TV and was able hold it somehow but it crashed with screen hitting my head, The TV still ran for another year until the display went dead completely one day. So it is a myth that the longevity of brands like TCL is not good, until some time back they used to manufacture panels for Samsung.
About the upscaling being discussed here. Sony and Samsung do upscaling like how Oppo phones take pics over enhancement, TCL won't over do it and keeps motion blur in Check, telling this after using a 2nd TCL Qled TV for over a year.
Rest people should decide on their own, I have seen how these products are rated low on online portals mostly due to installation issues from platform n not due to disappointment with TV quality.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.
comments.comment_text_original:

Vision 9 got it all, all the USB ports u want (incl. 3.0), HDMI's u want, Dolby-Vision, Dolby-Atmos, ALLM, many many features in OS to control brightness, audio. comments.comment_text_display:
‚Äã@yenneferofgyanvapi3965I'm of the opposite opinion - an entry level OLED like the B5 really pales in comparison to even the C4.
It lacks the HDR impact. People say brightness doesn't matter, but it's useless brightness that doesn't matter. Having the headroom of brightness gives you better shadow detail and makes scenes pop. People wouldn't be buying C5s and G5s if blacks were the only thing that matters in picture quality.
MiniLED backlighting has come a very long way. I recommend you checking out the QM7/8K in person!

comments.comment_text_display: They are literally excluding the best TV of them all which is the Panasonic z95b.. 144 HZ as opposed to 165 for gaming is really negligible, but the Panasonic is definitely above the G5.. brightness is pretty damn close. And Panasonic is just known for premium quality. They took LG's panel and made a better television with it

The QN900F also makes for an excellent "upscale" alternative to the '25 Samung Frame Pro because of it's Art Store/Mode albeit without the wireless one connect box. I actually think because of its design, the matte screen, and that specific feature set makes it a great lifestyle tv and for that reason I think it should be actually compared to the Samsung Frame Series - I think Samsung missed the boat on not marketing this as a higher-end Frame TV; I have this tv and use it in art mode all the time where it blends in my with picture art frames on my wall. Samsung sent me  a 65" Frame Pro with a defective wireless one connect box a few months ago and sent me the 65" QN900F as a concession replacement since they had no replacement Frame Pro's in stock at the time and I was blown away about how comparable the art mode was to the frame pro series but with significantly better TV watching quality.
